title: Who Suggests the First Date?
situation: You’ve been chatting for a few days. The vibe is good, but no one has mentioned meeting up yet.
question: How do you move things forward?

choices.label: Wait for them to bring it up so you don’t seem too eager.
choices.outcome: Sometimes they eventually ask; other times the connection stalls and quietly fades.
choices.insight: Waiting can feel safe, but it also means giving up control over whether anything ever happens.

choices.label: Say, “I’ve really enjoyed chatting — want to grab a coffee sometime this week?”
choices.outcome: You learn quickly whether they’re open to meeting. Even a no gives you useful clarity.
choices.insight: Clear, low-pressure invitations are often read as confidence, not desperation.

choices.label: Hint indirectly with “We should hang sometime lol” and hope they pick it up.
choices.outcome: Some people don’t catch the hint or feel unsure how serious you are.
choices.insight: Indirect suggestions feel safer but are easier to ignore or misinterpret.

title: Choosing a First-Date Activity
situation: You’re trying to pick a first-date idea that isn’t boring but also doesn’t feel like a huge commitment.
question: What do you suggest?

choices.label: A three-hour fancy dinner at an expensive restaurant.
choices.outcome: It can feel high-pressure and hard to leave gracefully if the chemistry isn’t there.
choices.insight: Long, high-stakes plans increase pressure instead of connection on a first meeting.

choices.label: “Want to grab a coffee and walk around the park near [place] this weekend?”
choices.outcome: It’s casual, public, and time-flexible. You can end after one drink or keep walking if it’s going well.
choices.insight: Time-boxed, easy-exit plans help both people relax, which is what actually supports chemistry.

choices.label: “Come over to my place and we’ll see what happens.”
choices.outcome: For many people, this feels unsafe or overly sexual for a first meeting.
choices.insight: Safety and comfort often matter more than originality on a first date.

title: Running Late
situation: You realize you’re going to be 15 minutes late to your first date because of traffic.
question: How do you handle it?

choices.label: Say nothing and hope they don’t mind waiting.
choices.outcome: They may feel disrespected or worry they’ve been stood up.
choices.insight: Silence often gets filled with anxious stories, not generous assumptions.

choices.label: Text as soon as you know, apologize, and give a realistic new ETA.
choices.outcome: They feel considered and can decide whether they’re okay waiting.
choices.insight: Respecting someone’s time early on sets a tone for the whole connection.

choices.label: Blame the traffic dramatically and complain about how awful your day is.
choices.outcome: The date starts with a heavy, negative tone.
choices.insight: Honesty about delay is helpful; emotional dumping is a different thing entirely.

title: End-of-Date Goodbye
situation: The date went well. You’re standing outside the venue, and it’s time to say goodbye.
question: What do you do?

choices.label: Leave without saying anything about seeing them again, to look cool and detached.
choices.outcome: They may assume you’re not interested and move on, even if you actually liked them.
choices.insight: Playing too cool can hide genuine interest and block momentum.

choices.label: Say, “I had a good time and would like to see you again if you’re up for it,” and then lean in slowly enough for them to respond.
choices.outcome: You’re clear and respectful, and they get a chance to match that energy or not.
choices.insight: Stating what you’d like while leaving space for their answer is both confident and considerate.

choices.label: Go in for a kiss without reading their body language or giving any verbal cue.
choices.outcome: If they’re not comfortable, the moment can feel abrupt or invasive.
choices.insight: Good first kisses are usually co-created, not taken for granted.
